{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jordan Ayew | image = 20150331 Mali vs Ghana 023.jpg | image_size = | caption = Jordan Ayew playing for Ghana in 2015 | fullname = Jordan Pierre Ayew{{cite web |title=List of Players |url=http://www.cafonline.com/userfiles/file/CAN2012/Group%20D%20teams.pdf |publisher=Confederation of African Football |format=PDF |page=4 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109004153/http://www.cafonline.com/userfiles/file/CAN2012/Group%20D%20teams.pdf |archivedate=9 November 2013 |deadurl=yes}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|9|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Marseille]], France | height = 1.82 m{{cite web |url=https://www.om.net/equipes/effectifs/joueurs/15172/ayew-jordan |title=Fiche joueur Jordan Ayew |publisher=Olympique de Marseille |accessdate=23 October 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150815024530/https://www.om.net/equipes/effectifs/joueurs/15172/ayew-jordan |archivedate=15 August 2015 |deadurl=no}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]
(on loan from [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]) | clubnumber = 14 | youthyears1 = 2000–2006 | youthclubs1 = [[AS Lyon Duchère|Lyon Duchère]] | youthyears2 = 2006–2009 | youthclubs2 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | years1 = 2009–2014 | clubs1 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | caps1 = 111 | goals1 = 14 | years2 = 2014 | clubs2 = → [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] (loan) | caps2 = 17 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2014–2015 | clubs3 = [[FC Lorient|Lorient]] | caps3 = 31 | goals3 = 12 | years4 = 2015–2017 | clubs4 = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] | caps4 = 51 | goals4 = 9 | years5 = 2017– | clubs5 = [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] | caps5 = 50 | goals5 = 8 | years6 = 2018– | clubs6 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) | caps6 = 18 | goals6 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2010 | nationalteam1 = [[Ghana national under-20 football team|Ghana U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2010– | nationalteam2 = [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] | nationalcaps2 = 51 | nationalgoals2 = 14 | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport|[[Association football|Football]]}} {{medalTeam|[[Olympique de Marseille]]}} {{medalW|[[Coupe de la Ligue]]|[[2010 Coupe de la Ligue Final|2010]]}} {{medalW|[[Ligue 1]]|[[2009–10 Ligue 1|2010]]}} {{medalW|[[Trophée des Champions]]|[[2010 Trophée des Champions|2010]]}} {{medalW|[[Coupe de la Ligue]]|[[2011 Coupe de la Ligue Final|2011]]}} {{medalW|[[Trophée des Champions]]|[[2011 Trophée des Champions|2011]]}} {{medalW|[[Coupe de la Ligue]]|[[2012 Coupe de la Ligue Final|2012]]}} | club-update = 20:19, 23 February 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 18 November 2018 }} '''Jordan Pierre Ayew''' (born 11 September 1991) is a Ghanaian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on loan from [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and the [[Ghana national football team|Ghana national team]]. He is the son of former Ghana captain [[Abedi Pele]] and brother of [[André Ayew]], who plays for [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]]. ==Club career== ===Marseille=== [[File:Valais Cup 2013 - OM-FC Porto 13-07-2013 - Maicon et Jordan Ayew.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Ayew playing for [[Olympique de Marseille]] in 2013]] Ayew joined [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] as a trainee in 2006. He signed a three-year professional [[Association football contracts|contract]] with Marseille in 2009. Jordan Ayew made his debut for the senior team on 16 December 2009 in a [[Ligue 1|league]] match, scoring the equaliser against [[FC Lorient|Lorient]]. [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] went on to win the match 2–1.{{LFP|id=ayew-jordan}} Ayew scored his second goal against [[OGC Nice|Nice]] at the [[Stade Vélodrome]] on 27 April 2011 in a match which saw his elder brother [[André Ayew]] score a [[Hat-trick#Football .28Association football.29|hat-trick]]. On 1 November 2011, Jordan and André both started a [[UEFA Champions League]] match for the first time against Premier League outfit [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. On 6 January 2014, he joined Ligue 1 rivals [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] on a loan deal until the end of the [[2013-14 Ligue 1|2013–14 season]].{{cite web|title=Jordan Ayew Officiellement Sochalien|url=http://www.fcsochaux.fr/fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5939 |publisher=FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|accessdate=6 January 2014|date=6 January 2014}} ===Lorient=== On 28 July 2014, Ayew signed a four-year contract with [[FC Lorient|Lorient]].{{cite web|title=Jordan Ayew FC Lorient decision|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28530377 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 July 2014|date=29 July 2014}} Ayew explained the style and quality of play that Lorient proposed was the reason behind the decision. ===Aston Villa=== On 27 July 2015, Ayew joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on a five-year deal for an undisclosed fee, reported to be in the region of £8 million.{{cite web|title=Breaking news: Villa sign Ayew |url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~4891745,00.html |publisher=Aston Villa |accessdate=27 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151118025652/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10265~4891745%2C00.html |archivedate=18 November 2015 }}{{cite web|title=Aston Villa bid for Lorient's Jordan Ayew accepted, according to Sky sources|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9922994/aston-villa-bid-for-lorients-jordan-ayew-accepted-according-to-sky-sources|publisher=SkySports|accessdate=27 July 2015|date=24 July 2015}} He scored his first goal for the club on 24 October 2015 against his elder brother's club, Swansea City, in the 62nd minute.{{cite web|title=Aston Villa 1–2 Swansea City|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34558441|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=10 November 2015}} Aston Villa were relegated at the end of the 2015–16 season, winning only 17 points, but Ayew did end the season as their top scorer, albeit with just seven goals. ===Swansea City=== On 31 January 2017, Jordan Ayew joined Swansea City in exchange for Welsh International defender [[Neil Taylor (footballer)|Neil Taylor]], plus a fee from Swansea that can rise to £5 million if undisclosed future conditions are met.{{cite news| title=Jordan Ayew: Swansea sign Aston Villa forward in Neil Taylor swap deal| url= https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38800257|work=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2017|accessdate=4 February 2017}} Jordan's elder brother was a Swansea City player during the 2015–16 season and later joined him in the winter transfer window of 2018.{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42767978 | title = Andre Ayew: Swansea City re-sign Ghana forward from West Ham | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 31 January 2018 | accessdate = 2 February 2018 }} ===Crystal Palace (loan)=== On transfer deadline day, Ayew joined Crystal Palace on loan for the [[2018–19 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2018–19 season]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2018/august/jordan-ayew-joins-crystal-palace/|title=Jordan Ayew Joins Crystal Palace|publisher = Crystal Palace F.C.|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}} ==International career== Ayew made his first senior [[Cap (sport)|appearance]] for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 5 September 2010, in a 3–0 [[2012 & 2013 Africa Cup of Nations qualification|2012 AFCON Qualification]] match win against Swaziland, at the [[Somhlolo National Stadium]] in [[Lobamba]], Swaziland.{{cite web|title=Ghana beats Swaziland 3–0 in 2012 qualifier|url=http://www.ghanafa.org/blackstars/201009/5034.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908090524/http://www.ghanafa.org/blackstars/201009/5034.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 September 2010|publisher=[[Ghana Football Association]]|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=5 September 2010}}{{cite web|title=Olympique de Marseille's Jordan Ayew Yearns For More With Ghana|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/89/africa/2010/09/07/2105589/olympique-de-marseilles-jordan-ayew-yearns-for-more-with |author=K.N.S Mensah|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=7 September 2010}} On 1 June 2012, Ayew scored his first and second international [[Goal (sport)|goals]] in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)#Group D|2014 World Cup qualification]] match win against Lesotho, at the [[Kumasi Sports Stadium]] in [[Kumasi]], Ghana.{{cite web|title=Ghana 7–0 Lesotho (2014 FIFA World Cup Qualifiers)|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/africa/matches/round=258334/match=300176007/index.html|publisher=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] (FIFA)|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=1 June 2012}} In December 2011, Ayew was named to the Ghana national team provisional 25-man squad for the [[2012 Africa Cup of Nations]],{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1658/ghana/2011/12/15/2804053/ghana-announce-25-man-squad-for-2012-africa-cup-of-nations|title=Ghana announce 25-man squad for 2012 Africa Cup of Nations|last=Mensah|first=Kent|accessdate=7 June 2012|date=15 December 2011|publisher=Goal.com}} and in January 2012 he was selected for the tournament's 23-man squad.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtnfootball.com/africa/african-tournaments/african-cup-of-nations/2012-player-profiles/ghana/jordan-ayew.html|title=Jordan Ayew – 2012 Africa Cup of Nations profile|accessdate=7 June 2012|work=mtnfootball.com|publisher=[[MTN Group]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007123731/http://www.mtnfootball.com/africa/african-tournaments/african-cup-of-nations/2012-player-profiles/ghana/jordan-ayew.html|archivedate=7 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} In June 2014, he was included in the Ghanaian squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]]. In Ghana's last warm-up match before the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil on 9 June 2014, Ayew came on as a first-half substitute for the injured [[Majeed Waris]] and ended up scoring a hat-trick in a 4–0 victory over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/fifa-world-cup/story/1863563/ghana-4-0-south-korea-ayew-hat-trick |title=Ghana wins final World Cup warmup |publisher=ESPNFC |date=9 June 2014 |accessdate=9 June 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gh/news/4389/ghana/2014/06/10/4871892/ghana-4-0-south-korea-j-ayews-hat-trick-inspires-confidence?ICID=HP_BN_1|title=Ghana 4–0 South Korea: J. Ayew's hat-trick inspires confidence ahead of World Cup|last=Mensah|first=Kent|accessdate=9 June 2014|date=10 June 2014|publisher=Goal.com}} Jordan Ayew was part of the 2015 Africa Cup of Nations team in [[Equatorial Guinea]] that took a silver medal as result of losing out to Ivory Coast on a penalty shoot out whom they clinch the [[African Cup]], which occurred on 8 February 2015. ==Personal life== Ayew is the son of Maha Ayew and [[Abedi Pele]]. His father, uncles [[Kwame Ayew|Kwame]] and Sola, and brothers [[André Ayew|André]], [[Ibrahim Ayew|Ibrahim]] and Imani are all current or former professional footballers. Ayew is a practising [[Muslim]].{{cite news|title=Picture: Jordan & Andre Ayew pictured in Muslim prayers|url=http://ghanasoccernet.com/picture-jordan-andre-ayew-pictured-in-muslim-prayers/|publisher=ghanasoccernet.com|date=21 December 2013|accessdate=4 April 2014}} ==Career statistics==
